They have a good selection of beverages, although I usually find myself grabbing some white wine. They are also open until midnight with no cover which is a plus if you find yourself kicked out of a nearby bar and just have to have another before you stagger to the night bus. They also seem to have a high percentage of cute guys there, not sure how they manage that, and no guarantees of course, ladies, but its a decent bet if you have a wandering eye!

9WSPOm27kqVadEG_84bCyg.text: Went there on a Monday night before close and it wasnt busy but it wasn't empty either.  Best beers I have had in London so far.  Their award winning Plain Porter is similar to Guinness but a lot better in my opinion.(i actually don't really like Guinness but found this to be a lot smoother). Also, if you like beer and you like banana bread then you must try the banana bread beer!  Surprisingly delicious!

kbVECsD9H6lkHJRy8gk0Yw.text: I'm almost embarrassed to admit how many times I came here!  Its a fine place and great prices and music, but I can't say that anything stuck out for me.  I would definitely recommend it to friends as a place to go.  I agree with Larissa about the stairs too....they are dizzying!

Emoi1reIGZxLLIqEMMhbSg.text: really cool place to go to :Dnice hide out, about 50+ kinds of beer, pub food, live music :)i think that the best thing about Porterhouse isthe look of it. beer pipes, shiny brass railings etc :) definitely a must go!

cIXIRn4FbbPo6vhlfgPu-A.text: Good bar with plenty of cubby holesand early to try and bag a seat though! Roll on the summer with the seating out the frontgood times to be had!

WU-kU2XzmQ88i71dKn09aA.text: A great location, venue and range of beers, unfortunately it is usually way too busy and the decor inside makes it kind of depressing, and easy to get lost! I think this bar has a lot of potential and could be amazing, it is certainly the place to go for a variety of beers. However I would usually walk past and go somewhere where I know it isn't going to be a battle to get to the bar, get served and then find my friends!

jLYdPWtyjEyVpuFH9c8odg.text: The Porterhouse is both good and bad - the choice of beers is very good but the pub itself is very ordinary. It's a good place to go out with a bunch of people and if you're a beer drinker you won't be disappointed with the choice. It's a real pity, however, that the design of the interior is so lacking in ambition - a bolder approach could have made the Porterhouse quite memorable.

uofpreHK91Nc6hHaxsnMyg.text: The Porterhouse has always been a favourite venue for work events from going away do's, to catch ups, to Christmas parties. Its an interesting pub that is much larger than you first imagine with what feels like about four of five different floors. Finding your mates is half the fun in this place which feels like a maze. The beer selection is wide-ranging. I was impressed with the bar tender who was able to juggle four customer orders at once and considering we'd all ordered about six drinks each it was a good effort. Generally this place gets so packed you can't move an inch so I was expecting the same last night (Wed) especially this close to Christmas but on the lower floor it wasn't so bad. We'd reserved an area as well so that helped. The only problem was the music was very loud but that was probably because we were right under a speaker.

XUir6zRbCZBYnqec5xpk6A.text: Went for a quick drink after dinner on a Tuesday. Not much going on there, but the surroundings were nice. Good option if you want a pub in Covent Garden area.

fDpsFiLNdCXm7YhYPwsxmg.text: A quite nice pub with some decent drinks on tap. The decor is nice and the atmosphere conducive to good times. I went to an engagement party upstairs once and it was relatively private so a good choice if you want to book some tables for an informal gathering. The bar staff were really friendly.

FfpE6LIREJJ3seqbLlkRRw.text: Good, lively pub in Covent Garden. Gets very busy and would be ideal before a night out, or a good place to meet up with a larger group of friends.

maJ2DEUCtiomK8ScrQcKOg.text: Huge on the inside, lovely outdoor area on the outside and right close to the Canadian shop, this is a lovely drinking hole. There are several beers on tap and the usual alcohol behind the bar. There are a number of surfaces to put your drink on or you can head out into the garden. This place was heaving when I wnet and yet service was superfast. There is a large bar area making getting service a breeze. The large inside area means there is a lot of space to find a place to gather together with friends. It is slightly hidden around the corner so don't be put off if you don't spot it. It is recessed from the road so just stick your nose around the corner and enjoy!

IvEhGfZCsUqzJABh2vZVrg.text: Do not even think about coming here if there is a rugby game on or if Ireland are playing anyone at anything! Seriously packed. During the big Ireland v England something or other match, we had to stand outside for almost an hour because it was allegedly too busy. Bouncers are complete tools as well. When I asked my friend why in the name of God she had chosen this bar to watch the match, she answered 'oh you have to come here, it's great craic' . So despite the dark gloomy interior, it is actually a great atmosphere for matches. I won't comment on the staircases 'cos if you've been to the Irish Porterhouses, you'll know that this is a standard feature. These bars are just brilliant for chilling with friends and sampling their own brews.

UD5mLYk0_-hTxB8Wu5U3qg.text: Large attractive & sprawling pub venue, has many different levels meaning it can pack in the crowds & makes it very hard to find people within! Very loud & noisy on weekends & bit of a meat market then too! Serves food (a bit on the pricey side) with standard menu offering burgers (approx £8.50), pizzas, stews etc.Does have a very big selection of beers on offer including the beloved Fruli fruit beer - mmmmm - don't knock it till you've tried it!Has live music at night from thurs - sun.

photos.caption: Photo of The Porterhouse Brew Co - London, United Kingdom

Vz2aw5izsIPkJqZnTb0fFw.text: I found myself wandering around Covent Garden with a friend, looking for a bar. We came across The Porterhouse with hordes of people chilling outside, so we decided to go in. WOW! This place was packed and sprawling! The beer list was impressive, with beers from many countries (except France, hah!). Downstairs there was a live band performing. On the ground floor and above (heck if I know how many floors there are) there are seats and counters all over the place, so you're bound to find somewhere to chill. It can get a little crazy and overly boisterous inside, but I suppose that's all part of the fun. It'd be a great place for groups (assuming you can find a spot).

BQSunI0qooGH4P4GCdBmNA.text: You know the famous 'impossible staircase' puzzle, the one where several figures are moving up and down different staircase but never meet at the same point? That's the Porter House for me. Not only is it huge and confusing with all it's nooks and in-between levels but it's always so busy in here that it's just impossible to find anyone. Don't think you can rely on your phone signal to help you out in here either...reach for your mobile and all you will see is a sad diagonal line across your reception bars indicating that there really is no way out from here. It's kind of like Hotel California.Still, if you're in a big crowd looking to watch the rugby then I would recommend the Porter House. Drink prices are what you would expect for Covent Garden but they do have a good selection of beers. If you're there early enough then you can make it up to the top floor and get a good seat with a view of one of the TV screens. Too late and you'll be stuck behind some corner listening to the cheers but not knowing who scored!

pdKvrwBcNZQN_cXj7krxwg.text: Part of the good kind of 'chain' pub: the original Porterhouse brewery and bar in Ireland proved so popular they've transported the model over here. Sadly, the Covent Garden incarnation is the, "worst" seems unfair, let's say: "least good" of the Porterhouses I've been to, but maybe that's down to the differing attitudes to drinking in Ireland and London... while the Irish will leisurely appreciate the distinctive beers on offer, with banter and craic aplenty, the London version attracts post-work boozing and shouty crowds. But, if you manage to avoid the crowds, you can still enjoy the 'home brewed' (in Ireland) brews: their stouts and porters are the highlight, but they have a version of nearly all beer types, from weiss to the darkest stouts. Plenty of the better international beers are available too. In fact with their beer menu and tasting notes, it makes for a good place to introduce someone to the wealth and range of beer flavours that are available beyond the standard lagers. Beer-lovers should visit, but leave before the crowds flood in, and go elsewhere to eat.

iSYTp1O_dn9_tvAOrysCqw.text: What can I say, it's a pub.Love the decor, I think it's interesting and a nice place for casual drinks, although from the sounds of things I don't think I'd like to go there at peak times. There are multiple levels and several bars dotted around. The wine list had some nice wines on it, but what you really go there for is the huge selection of beers on offer. That said, my glass of NZ sauv was great. I think next time I go there I'll go for the beer tasting option, which gives you a selection of beers to try.The outdoor seating area is a bit hit and miss  I think they need to rethink their chair and table options to make the place look a bit more welcoming, classy and a bit less like the cheap seats you get in a classroom. It's scrappy and could do better with some larger wooden picnic style tables rather than tiny little two seaters.

B-0iI-lUDtTOSOYAjtqWaA.text: This is a huge bar with a massive collection of beer from different countries.  This bar can get really crowded, but I see this as a good thing, especially when you're new in the country.  The downstairs area is for what is on tap while the upstairs has the bottled beers.  I took a friend of mine here who was looking for something different other than the regular club experience and he really seemed to enjoy himself.  I was really craving a Sam Adams and was able to find one here.  We also went nuts when a cover band started playing Oasis.  Sorry, sometimes I just have those moments. Note:  You have to go down some side streets to find this place, so it's easy to get lost.

w-CYeh91MeNVWBopQejCaA.text: Not a good place for a blind date for the following reason: The Porterhouse is vast, ridiculously huge with multiple levels and all sorts of nooks and crannies. There is not a chance in hell you would ever find someone you have never met before in here unless it was completely empty, and even then, you would struggle. I ended up phoning my friends about three times just to find them.I would however, recommend this place for a lads night or for watching sports. The bar offers a huge range of different beers, both on tap and bottled. You could while away a happy hour or two trying as many of them as possible and getting truly sozzled.

WPv-N_-57-S5U6-fXTqSZA.text: Great place for a beer or 2 with friends.Not a place to meet friends in - its a Labrynth! - best to meet nearby (like All Bar One) and then head in together.A huge selection of beers (they have beer thatis around 10% ABV!)Various different types of people there... a good night out!

Dm8Q8eFUnYzsCq7au1PMzg.text: Massive place, really good atmosphere, huge choice of beers and great decor! Would so recommend for drinks and night out! Plenty of people and loud music.

FbrBNC7e28Uh7-b30c7qTw.text: I didn't eat here, but their beers were very good, and this coming from a Colorado boy used to good beer. Their award-winning Plain Porter is very nice, but I thought the Oyster Stout superior. The Red had some nice hops and once it warmed up (all the beers were served too cold for proper judging) was really nice.

3oLLMtOq1uHCXMXkc29f7Q.text: I guess mostly everyone else has glossed over the fact that this is a microbrewery, first and foremost, started in Dublin, Ireland. In fact, The Porterhouse is the largest Irish-owned brewery in all of Ireland. Guinness is, in fac,t no longer Irish and is part of a giant conglomerate of breweries that primarily sponsor sporting events rather than focus on quality beers.The Porterhouse Covent Garden is an impressive pub with many nooks and crannies to enjoy a nice pint with friends. My favorite is the Wrasslers XXXX Stout followed closely by the Plain Porter. '4X' as it's known, is a lovely Irish stout with a fresh, rich and creamy taste and a nice full head that you would expect from a beer of this style. Wrasslers  that I'm sure at some point Guinness once resembled. In my opinion, 4X is THE best Irish stout, hands down. I've imbibed a fair bit of Wrasslers in one go and I must say it was the only time I did not get a rotten hangover that is usually associated with a long night with Guinness.If a stout isn't your thing, give the Plain Porter a shot, it's lighter and quicker drinking if you're out for a long session with friends. If THAT'S not your thing, then try Brain Blásta for a lovely blast of 7% ABV to your head in the form of a malty-sweet ale that resembles those made famous by Belgian monks. Further down the line, the Oyster Stout must be tasted to be fully understood (it's made from real oysters) and the Temple Brau lager is the only lager I would dream of drinking in an Irish pub. The Porterhouse Red is a lovely Irish red ale that puts Smithwicks (Diageo/Guinness) to shame. My only gripe is that The Porterhouse beer is not available anywhere else but their pubs. But I guess that's what makes them so much more special...I only gave The Porterhouse Covent Garden 4 stars simply because the best is still the Original in Dublin's famous Temple Bar cultural quarter on Parliament Street.As for the other beers not reviewed: Hersbrucker, TSB, and Chiller, I have not tasted them so I won't review them for now. So it looks like I'm due for another trip to The Porterhouse microbrewery...

UKuyiy9s_zmGBO4jnvcIWg.text: I really like this pub because of the building and the extensive range of beers on offer. It's a large place with staircases winding up and down to various floors that hold plenty of nooks and crannies to sit in which creates a really great place to enjoy a drink. In the summer they set up a barbeque outside which always attracts a big crowd.  The beer range is incredible here-there's all kinds of weird and wonderful beers and ales to try and they have a pretty extensive food menu offering oysters, mussels and some fine burgers and pizzas all at prices that won't break the bank. I love Porterhouse because being there becomes an experience rather than just going out for a drink as you become intrigued to try all of their offerings and the building itself is great to be in and explore. It's a perfect place to take a group of friends because there's plenty of large tables and seating areas. Porterhouse is always busy and I can totally understand why-this is one of my top pubs to visit in London.

I know I've been here in the past and enjoyed it so I'll give it another try sometime. Perhaps not on Saturday night though!
